Description: Body sherd of Attic-black figured pottery closed vessel; interior reserved. Exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of Dionysos (with added red himation, red dots surrounded by added white dots on vertical fold), stands to the left, holding a kantharos (with white dots on rim and lower bowl) in his left hand and a grape vine (one bunch in red, one with spots) in his right hand; beside him, Ariadne (white knuckes of right hand visible beside Dionysos’ right hand), to right and holding a drinking horn in her left hand (in white); at right, possibly Hermes standing, to right and wearing short chiton with spotted skin tied around it; uncertain dappled object on foreground below right. On joining fragment Bonn 697.99, Hermes stands facing right (small part of torso, lower body, thigh of advanced left (?) leg remaining) wearing a spotted animal skin tied over a short chiton with wide border (two rows of dots between double lines); his body is crossed by parts of the large kantharos and, lower down by his thigh, the bunch of grapes; at the right is the middle part of a draped male figure standing facing left, holding an upright staff (perhaps part of a spear) in his right hand, while the fingers of his left hand are spread out diagonally against his himation (decorated with disks in added red).
Curator's comments: For another sherd attributed to an artist near the Affecter, see Oxford AN1896-1908-G.137.51 from Naukratis. The sherd joins Bonn 697.99.
The shape can scarcely be an amphora, if height of frieze, thinness of wall and curvature are taken into account.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.49)
Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 264, no. 43)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 208, no. B27)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 234, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0079) (Phase 1)
